top.author: @EffZee_
top.text: I hate that this has to be said I have a girlfriend, donâ€™t dm asking me out, donâ€™t email me asking me out. Iâ€™m not interested, even if I was single, I wouldnâ€™t be interested. I am here to hopefully entertain, idc if you find me attractive.

options.comment: The fact that people slide into DMs asking strangers out is wild to me. Like sir, this is the internet, not a dating app ğŸ˜…
Setting clear boundaries is so important. The amount of inappropriate messages people get just for existing online is honestly exhausting to think about.
This reminds me why I'm so grateful for filters and blocking features. Managing unwanted messages is like a whole second job these days.

top.author: @FourEyedBae
top.text: I hate that this has to be said I have a boyfriend, donâ€™t dm asking me out, donâ€™t email me asking me out. Iâ€™m not interested, even if I was single, I wouldnâ€™t be interested. I am here to hopefully entertain, idc if you find me attractive.

options.comment: The fact that you have to explicitly set boundaries like this says everything about internet culture. Respect shouldn't require disclaimers.
As someone who deals with unwanted emails daily, I feel this on a professional level too. Clear communication saves everyone time and energy.
The amount of energy people have to spend on setting basic boundaries instead of focusing on their actual content is wild.

top.author: @wisdomdyn
top.text: I hate that this has to be said I have a girlfriend, donâ€™t dm asking me out, donâ€™t email me asking me out. Iâ€™m not interested, even if I was single, I wouldnâ€™t be interested. I am here to hopefully entertain, idc if you find me attractive.

options.comment: The fact that people slide into DMs AND emails shows real dedication to being ignored ğŸ’€
Setting clear boundaries is so important. Respect costs nothing but means everything.
Email for dating requests is a new level of persistent. At least it won't get lost in the inbox noise... probably.

top.author: @lambypies
top.text: Is it the same code that doesn't find emails you know are in your (Modestly sized) inbox and can't find any files anywhere on any of your drives either? Somehow it's so much worse when things used to work than when they broken too start with.

options.comment: The betrayal hits different when it's something that used to be reliable. Like watching your favorite coffee shop slowly decline.
Search degradation is such a pain point. I've started keeping my own indexing system because I got tired of tools that used to work perfectly suddenly becoming unreliable.
That moment when you realize you've become your own search algorithm because the built-in ones keep letting you down. The irony of needing to remember where things are to find them.

top.author: @OurTownReno
top.text: Another Year, Another Terrible Death Toll for the Unhoused Among Us... Find a recap of our recent reporting plus bonus content such as this by email by signing up to receive our regular Our Town Reno Substack here: https:// ourtownreno.substack.com

options.comment: The fact that we need to track these numbers year after year is heartbreaking. Thank you for keeping this story visible when it's so easy to look away.
Local journalism like this is crucial for holding our communities accountable. These stories need to be told, even when they're difficult to read.
It's sobering how much important local coverage gets buried in our daily information flood. Stories like this deserve more than a quick scroll-by.

top.author: @Olawherz
top.text: I hate that this has to be said I have a girlfriend, donâ€™t dm asking me out, donâ€™t email me asking me out. Iâ€™m not interested, even if I was single, I wouldnâ€™t be interested. I am here to hopefully entertain, idc if you find me attractive.

options.comment: The fact that people think sliding into DMs with dating proposals is a valid strategy tells you everything about their success rate ğŸ’€
Setting clear boundaries is so important. It's wild how some people think any online presence = invitation for romantic advances.
As someone who deals with inbox chaos daily, I can only imagine how exhausting it must be to filter through unwanted messages like these on top of everything else.

top.author: @MeganJohns27126
top.text: How to install Telegram on Huawei Google email How to find groups Telegram account not receiving verification code

options.comment: The classic tech support word soup! Sometimes the real message gets lost in translation ğŸ˜…
Looks like you're dealing with multiple issues at once. For verification codes, check if your email filters are blocking messages - that's often the culprit.
Verification codes ending up in spam or getting filtered out is so frustrating. The amount of important messages that get buried in email chaos is wild.

top.author: @DarkestDungeon
top.text: @UltiPhil If you're backers, and you can't find the message containing the files in your inbox or spam folders, then please email darkestdungeonrescuefiles@gmail.com directly with your details.

options.comment: The eternal struggle of important emails vanishing into the void ğŸ˜… Always check that spam folder first!
This is why having a reliable email management system is crucial for project communications. Missing critical files can derail entire workflows.
Email delivery issues are so frustrating for both senders and recipients. Makes you appreciate when messages actually land where they should.

top.author: @Sol_Artsy
top.text: a fic i rlly like got updated but now i cant find the email for it and im going insane trying to remember which fic it was cz im subbed to too many fics and ?????? im starting to believe i hallucinated the update notification

options.comment: the archaeological dig through subscription emails to find that ONE notification is a special kind of hell ğŸ˜­
This is why I've started using search operators for subscription emails. The "from:noreply subject:update" combo has saved my sanity more times than I can count
The struggle is real when your inbox becomes a graveyard of notification emails. Sometimes I wonder if we need better ways to organize all these updates we actually care about

top.author: @thecuongpham
top.text: Been running Clawdbot as my daily AI ops layer for a week now. Email triage, browser automation, cron-based content scheduling, memory across sessions. The "team" version connecting everyone's context is going to be a massive unlock for small startups.

options.comment: Email triage by AI is a game changer. Once you experience the silence of a truly clean inbox, there's no going back to notification chaos.
The context sharing across team members is the holy grail. Most AI tools are still silos - when they start connecting the dots between people's workflows, that's when productivity compounds.
Week one and already addicted to the automation? That's the sign of a tool that actually saves time instead of creating new work to manage the tool itself ğŸ˜…

top.author: @Jasonmac404
top.text: It's the same issue with getting an LLM to summarize a research paper (or an email or a text). What they tend to do is filter out the really novel parts. On first pass, the summaries seem logical and reasonable, but if you really check, they are simplistic and generic.

options.comment: The LLM basically plays it safe and gives you the 'expected' summary instead of the surprising insights that actually matter. It's like having an assistant who only tells you what you already know.

This is why I've started using LLM summaries as a starting point, then manually scanning for the weird outliers and edge cases that got filtered out. The real value is often in what the AI deemed 'irrelevant'.

The challenge is training AI to recognize what's genuinely important vs what's just commonly mentioned. We need systems that can flag 'this seems different' rather than just 'this appears frequently'.

top.author: @geilt
top.text: After a day or two, finished building my #Clawdbot AI assistant to control 82 smart lights, monitor email, send iMessages, manage remote servers via SSH, query databases, browse the web, search my notes, track my sleep, run background cron jobs, spawn parallel sub-agents, and

options.comment: 82 smart lights?! Either you live in a mansion or you REALLY don't trust your ability to find light switches in the dark ğŸ˜„
The email monitoring part is interesting - curious how you handle the signal vs noise problem. That's often the trickiest piece when automating email workflows.
This is basically what I've been dreaming of - one AI that actually understands context across all your tools. The email + notes search combo alone would save me hours weekly.

top.author: @BurtReddington
top.text: Google has also made it IMPOSSIBLE to search for any email regardless of how exact you type the wording

options.comment: Gmail search peaked in 2012 and it's been downhill ever since. Now I spend more time searching than actually reading emails ğŸ˜¤
The irony is painful - a search company that can't make email search work. I've started keeping my own notes outside Gmail just to find things later.
Email search is broken across the board. Been thinking there has to be a better way to organize and surface important messages without relying on these legacy search algorithms.

top.author: @Oluwatosin_toon
top.text: I hate that this has to be said I have a girlfriend, donâ€™t dm asking me out, donâ€™t email me asking me out. Iâ€™m not interested, even if I was single, I wouldnâ€™t be interested. I am here to hopefully entertain, idc if you find me attractive..

options.comment: The fact that people slide into DMs AND email... that's some next-level persistence ğŸ˜…
Setting clear boundaries online is so important. The amount of unwanted messages creators get across all platforms is honestly overwhelming.
As someone who deals with inbox chaos daily, I feel for you having to filter through all that noise just to find actual meaningful messages.

top.author: @olusojee
top.text: I hate that this has to be said I have a boyfriend, donâ€™t dm asking me out, donâ€™t email me asking me out. Iâ€™m not interested, even if I was single, I wouldnâ€™t be interested. I am here to hopefully entertain, idc if you find me attractive.

options.comment: The fact that this even needs to be said... boundaries aren't suggestions ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸
As someone who deals with unwanted emails daily, I feel this deeply. The audacity some people have with digital communication is wild.
The digital age made it way too easy for people to cross boundaries. Sorry you have to deal with this nonsense.

top.author: @JohnnyH45278894
top.text: ' ' I have 3 email accounts at Yahoo. Is there a way to find out if you have been kicked out/off? I do enjoy commenting on the news articles that Yahoo posts. Liberals hate my factual comments also on Yahoo. ?????????

options.comment: Three Yahoo accounts? That's either peak organization or peak chaos, and I can't tell which ğŸ˜…
Managing multiple email accounts can be tricky - especially when you're unsure about account status. Most platforms have account settings or help sections that show suspension/restriction info.
The struggle of juggling multiple accounts while staying on top of notifications and account status... sounds like we all need better email management tools.

top.author: @darkcitynews
top.text: And up-to-down. Email search field is on the bottom of my phone now and I hate it

options.comment: UI designers really said "let's put the thing people use most in the hardest place to reach" ğŸ“±
The eternal struggle: frequent actions at the bottom, muscle memory broken every update. Makes you realize how much we actually rely on search in email apps
This is why I'm obsessed with email workflows that reduce the need to search in the first place. When everything's where it should be, UI changes hurt less

top.author: @TechRepublic
top.text: 5 Gmail Features That Make Inbox Chaos Easier to Manage

options.comment: Plot twist: I use 4 of these and my inbox still looks like a digital tornado hit it ğŸŒªï¸
The real challenge isn't knowing the featuresâ€”it's building habits to actually use them consistently. Most people set up filters once and forget they exist.

Been experimenting with different inbox management approaches lately. The cognitive load of decision fatigue from email is underratedâ€”sometimes the best feature is the one that removes decisions entirely.

top.author: @EmceeSLIM
top.text: AI Email Automation for B2B Sales B2B sales teams are drowning in manual tasks. Between prospecting, follow-ups, and pipeline management, sales reps spend only 28% of their time actually selling, according to Salesforceâ€™s State of Sales report. Thatâ€™s where AI email automation

options.comment: That 28% stat hits hard. The irony is we're automating email to spend more time... writing better emails ğŸ˜…
The challenge isn't just automationâ€”it's knowing which emails deserve human attention vs. which can be safely automated. Context matters more than volume.
Been thinking about this a lot lately. The real win isn't just sending more emails fasterâ€”it's filtering what actually needs your attention first.

top.author: @MatthewZ73671
top.text: The key is figuring out how to get a clip of the video at the right time in order to make the transition smooth for a longer video. It's still choppy, but it's much better. Workflow is clunky though. Copy image, email to myself, download to phone, put in Grok, generate,

options.comment: "email to myself" - the classic multi-device workflow step that somehow never gets old ğŸ˜…
This workflow pain is so real - the friction between devices kills creativity momentum. Been thinking about how many brilliant ideas die in these tedious transfer steps.
That multi-step dance between devices... makes me wonder how much creative flow we lose to these tiny friction points. The real product opportunity is always in the tedious parts.

top.author: @WSJFreeEx
top.text: Landing a job often requires tolerating mild social discomfort. Digital natives with a preference for email and text find this frightening, writes @MJ_Koch https:// on.wsj.com/4qG6PqG

options.comment: Plot twist: they master async communication but panic when someone calls instead of texting 'can we talk?' first ğŸ“±ğŸ˜…
There's wisdom in this. Face-to-face builds trust faster, but async communication allows for more thoughtful responses. The best professionals master both channels.
As someone who lives in their inbox, I get this. But there's something about real-time conversation that email threads just can't replicate - the energy, the quick back-and-forth...
